Scheme 1 Synthetic scheme of porphyrin organic polymers(R = H or F). Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Synthetic scheme of metalloporphyrin organic polymers (R = H or F, M = Co or Fe). Scheme 2 Fig. 1 FT-IR spectra of a) (Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP and Co(Por)OP; b) F(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, and CoF(Por)OP illustrating the absence of C = O band stretch and the presence of M-N and C-F bond stretches; PXRD diffractograms of c) (Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP and Co(Por)OP; d) F(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, and CoF(Por)OP showing that the polymers have an amorphous surface. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of (a) (Por)OP, (b) Co(Por)OP, (c) Fe(Por)OP, (d) F(Por)OP, (e) CoF(Por)OP and (f) FeF(Por)OP showing spherical morphology of the as synthesized polymers. Fig 2 Fig. 3 High resolution XPS spectrum of Fe and Co based polymers a) CoF(Por)OP showing Co in the 2+ oxidation state; b) FeF(Por)OP showing Fe in the 2+oxidation state; c) Co(Por)OP showing Co in the 2+oxidation state; and d) Fe(Por)OP showing Fe in the 2+oxidation state. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Cyclic Voltammograms with 100 % iR compensation of (Por)OP, F(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, CoF(Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP and carbon black in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte solutions saturated with oxygen gas; Scan rate: 10 mV/s. b) The corresponding Tafel plots for Co(Por)OP, CoF(Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP illustrating the kinetics of the reaction. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and the corresponding equivalent electric circuits. Nyquist plot of CoFPoR(OP), CoPor(OP) (A), and FeFPoR(OP), FePor(OP) (B). Simulated equivalent circuit of CoFPoR(OP), CoPor(OP) (C) and FeFPoR(OP), FePor(OP) (D). Fig 5 Fig. 6 a) Linear correlation between the average current density vs scan rates yielding the double layer capacitance (Cdl) of CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP in 0.5 M H2SO4 and the respective calculated electrochemical active surface area; b) ECSA normalized CV curves of CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, and Fe(Por)OP. Fig 6 Fig. 7 a) Cyclic Voltammograms with 100 % iR compensation of (Por)OP, F(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, CoF(Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP and carbon black in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte solution; Scan rate: 10 mV/s; b) The corresponding Tafel plots for Co(Por)OP, CoF(Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP illustrating the kinetics of the reaction. Fig 7 Fig. 8 a) Linear correlation between the average current density vs scan rates yielding the double layer capacitance (Cdl) of CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP in 0.5 M H2SO4 and the respective calculated electrochemical active surface area; b) ECSA normalized CV curves of CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, and Fe(Por)OP (insert image shows current densities). Metalloporphyrin polymers have attracted much attention due to their efficient electron transfer, their ability to form metal-oxo adducts, and due to their improved mass transport and efficiency. Here, we report cobalt and iron porphyrin-based organic polymers as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for the oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) in basic and acidic solutions. The porphyrin organic polymers (Por)OP and F(Por)P were synthesized from a one-step condensation reaction without further cross-coupling followed by direct metalation to form the metalloporphyrin polymers: Co(Por)OP, CoF(Por)P, Fe(Por)OP, and FeF(Por)P. Both metalated porphyrin polymers are active for the oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction with moderate overpotentials and Tafel slope in the range of 72.8 to 91.7 mV dec‑1 for OER and 131 to 167 mV dec‑1 for HER. At the same time, the metal-free (Por)OP and F(Por)OP show poor catalytic activity. These metalloporphyrin organic polymers show a remarkable stability of up to 14 h, whereas the cobalt polymers exhibit a Faradaic efficiency of 99 % for OER. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Porphyrin Polymers Water splitting OER HER Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The depletion of fossil fuels and their environmental impacts drive researchers to explore renewable energy technologies. Electrochemical water splitting, which combines the hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions (HER) and (OER), respectively, is a promising sustainable alternative to the energy crisis. Hydrogen, with its zero-carbon print and high energy density, is expected to play a key role in energy conversion [1]. Additionally, OER plays a fundamental role in energy conversion and storage systems, such as rechargeable metal-air batteries, fuel cells, and water electrolyzers [2,3]. In metal-air batteries, the key reaction (OER) is generally the major bottleneck in the development of more practical and widely applicable devices. OER is significant in that it dictates the reaction rate and efficiency of the water-splitting reaction [4,5]. Today, state-of-the-art electrocatalysts for HER and OER are based on precious metal reactivity (e.g., Pt and IrOx). Their high price and material scarcity have hampered their feasibility of commercialization. This has led to a magnitude of research, searching for more efficient alternative electrocatalysts for these two processes that can achieve overpotentials (η) close to the thermodynamic limits while increasing reaction rates. Recent steps have been taken toward the development of non-precious metal-based metal oxides, nitrides, carbides, and chalcogenides as electrocatalysts for oxygen generation [6–10]. The integration of redox-active molecular units into complexes with earth-abundant metals, such as cobalt, nickel, iron, and manganese, into networks, has shown increased stability and activity toward water splitting [11–19]. These efforts have enhanced the fundamental understanding of catalytic processes and have guided the rational design of efficient electrocatalysts. Despite the progress made, it remains a great challenge to achieve a balance between catalyst performance, cost, and stability. This must be further addressed before these energy conversion systems can be implemented on a large scale. Porphyrin-based materials, such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [20–23], covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [24–27], amorphous polymers [28–30], and composites [31–33], have been widely used in energy-related conversion processes, including the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2). Porphyrins are a group of nitrogen-rich organic compounds with extended 18 π-conjugated structures. Uniquely, this structure lends to characteristic multi-electron and proton transfer processes [34]. Introducing different functional groups on the periphery of porphyrins can tune electronic structure, therefore regulating their physical and chemical properties towards catalyzing HER and OER [35–40]. Extensive research on the effects of varied substituent groups on the behavior of the electrochemical activity of porphyrins has been conducted [41]. Our previous work has revealed the superior catalytic activity of free-base porphyrin bearing electron-withdrawing groups on the meso‑positions for the electrochemical generation of hydrogen [42]. Transition metal-based metalloporphyrins with biochemical inspiration (hemoglobin) have been frequently studied as (photo)electrocatalysts for water electrolysis [43–47]. Deprotonated porphyrin units have a strong ability to coordinate with high valence transition metals or metal ions by forming a rigid four-coordination center environment. These complexes are consistently active toward OO bond cleavage and formation [48,49]. Transition metals such as Co, Ni, Cu, and Fe have been rationally chosen as especially reactive active sites for oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions [50,51]. This is mainly due to their efficient electron transfer and ability to form metal-oxo adducts that can facilitate the four-electron reduction/oxidation with efficient selectivity. However, Fe-porphyrins showed only moderate electrocatalytic OER activity [52–54]. Considering water oxidation as the reverse reaction of oxygen reduction and the electrochemical tunability of porphyrin complexes, through proper design, it is possible to dramatically improve the OER activity of Fe-porphyrins. Additionally, the systematic heterogenization of metalloporphyrin moieties in polymer/framework will increase their recyclability and, more importantly, address issues such as low mass transport efficiency, poor stability, and low density of catalytically active sites [28,32,55,56]. Also, linker units with different electronegativities can affect electron transfer efficiency when combined with various metal centers within porphyrin units. As a result, the electronic structures can be tailored to improve the overall efficiency of OER [57]. In this work, we report the synthesis and characterization of easily synthesized porphyrin organic polymers from one-step polymerization and their metalated versions as efficient electrocatalysts for OER and HER. The introduction of Co and Fe in the porphyrin unit can serve as active sites, which result in faster reaction rates and significantly improved overall electrocatalytic performance. Furthermore, perfluorination of the linker in the metalated porphyrin polymers gave rise to enhanced OER overpotentials and kinetics. All materials were characterized using standard spectroscopic and microscopic techniques. We also herein report the evaluation of the electrocatalytic OER and HER performance of each of the polymers through electrochemical analysis. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials All chemicals used were purchased from commercially available sources. Pyrrole (C4H5N), terephthaldehyde (C8H6O2), FeCl2∙4H2O, and Nafion® 117 (5 % w/w in H2O and 1-propanol) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Co(OAc)2∙4H2O was purchased from TCI Chemicals. Carbon black (Vulcan XC-72) was obtained from the Fuel Cell Store. All solvents used and potassium hydroxide (KOH) pellets (>85 %) were from Fisher Scientific. Pyrrole was freshly distilled before use, while all other chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Physical and chemical characterization and methods 2.2.1 Physical and chemical characterization Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded using an Agilent Cary 630 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with an attenuated total reflectance (ATR) accessory. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were obtained using a Bruker D8 Discovery X-ray diffractometer. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) measurements along with elemental mapping and energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) were recorded on a Hitachi S-4800 instrument equipped with an EDX microanalysis system. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were obtained by a Physical Electronics PHI 5000 VersaProbe with an Al Kα source. All spectra were calibrated to the adventitious carbon 1 s peak at 284.8 eV and fitted using a Shirley background. Gas detection was performed using gas chromatography (GC) Shimadzu G8A. Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) measurements were performed using a PerkinElmer Avio 500. The samples were first digested in an aqua regia matrix (20 mL) overnight at 80 °C, then centrifuged to separate the undigested material, and diluted to 50 mL with Milli-Q purified water. 2.2.2 Working electrode preparation A catalyst ink was prepared by dispersing 2.5 mg of carbon black and 5 mg of catalyst in 1.02 mL isopropanol and 4.08 µL Nafion® solution. The resulting solution was sonicated for 30 min to form a homogeneous ink. A glassy carbon disk was cleaned and polished to a mirror finish and mounted on a rotating disk electrode (RDE) apparatus. The working electrode consisted of 10 µL of the prepared catalyst ink drop-casted on a glassy carbon disk, which was rotated at 600 RPM for 5 min until the ink was dry. The glassy carbon disk electrode (0.196 cm2) had a final catalyst loading of 0.25 mg cm-2. 2.2.3 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical measurements were conducted in a three-electrode RDE configuration using an Ag/AgCl reference electrode, a Pt wire counter electrode, and the modified glassy carbon disk as the working electrode. All studies were performed in a 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution saturated with ultra-high purity O2 , with the working electrode constantly rotated at 1600 rpm at a scan rate of 10 mV s-1. An ohmic correction was performed after each electrochemical measurement, and the resistance of the electrolyte solution in the cell was determined at 100 kHz. The RHE (reversible hydrogen electrode) potential was determined by measuring the open-circuit potential of a clean Pt electrode in the electrolyte solution after testing the electrodes. Faradaic efficiency was determined by quantitative oxygen gas determination from oxygen bubbles evolving from the working electrode that was captured in the H-type electrochemical cell. 2.3 Synthesis of porphyrin organic polymer [(Por)OP and F(Por)P]:[28] The general synthetic scheme is shown in Scheme 1 . Terephthalaldehyde (0.500 g, 3.73 mmol) or 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoroterephthalaldehyde (0.768 g, 3.73 mmol) was dissolved in propionic acid (400 mL) while freshly distilled pyrrole (0.250 g, 3.73 mmol) was slowly added to the terephthalaldehyde solution with constant stirring. The reaction mixture was allowed to react under reflux conditions for 12 h. The resultant product was cooled down and filtered using a medium coarse filter frit and was washed thoroughly with (1) deionized water, (2) methanol, (3) tetrahydrofuran, and finally (4) dichloromethane. The filtered and washed product was vacuum dried at 80 °C to remove any residual solvents and to obtain the final product as a black powder [Yield: F(Por)OP: 0.705 g, 79.40 %; (Por)OP: 0.459 g, 74.10 %]. 2.4 Synthesis of cobalt porphyrin organic polymer [(Co(Por)OP) and CoF(Por)OP] and iron porphyrin organic polymer [(Fe(Por)OP) and FeF(Por)OP]:[28] The general synthetic scheme is shown in Scheme 2 . In separate syntheses, (Por)OP or F(Por)OP (0.325 g) and the corresponding metal salts [Co(OAc)2∙4H2O and FeCl2∙4H2O] (1.10 g) were dissolved in a mixture solvent of propionic acid and DMF (400 mL, v/v = 2:1). The reaction mixtures were heated under reflux in a Schlenk flask under an inert atmosphere with constant stirring for 3 days. The solutions were subsequently cooled down and filtered using a medium coarse filter frit. The black filter cake was washed with deionized water, methanol, and dimethylformamide and vacuum dried at 80 °C to remove any residual solvents. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization FT-IR spectra and X-ray powder (PXRD) diffractograms of (Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, and Fe(Por)OP are in agreement with previous studies [25]. Notably, all FT-IR spectra do not show the characteristic C = O vibration band of the aldehyde between 1720 and 1740 cm-1 shown in Fig. 1 A and 1B (gray shade). This band is expected to diminish after successful polymerization, indicating that all samples are polymeric systems. The band observed at around 1001 cm-1 (highlighted by a red dotted line in Figs. 1A and 1B) for Co(Por)OP, Fe(Por)OP, CoF(Por)OP, and FeF(Por)OP is assigned to the characteristic metal-nitrogen vibration, suggesting successful metalation. The peaks observed at around 1298 cm-1 in the fluorinated samples (Fig. 1B) are attributed to the C‒F stretch. All PXRD diffractograms confirm the amorphous nature of the synthesized materials, evidenced by the presence of broad diffraction features rather than sharp Bragg reflections. In the unfluorinated series (Fig. 1C), (Por)OP exhibits a broad peak at 2θ = 19.3°, corresponding to an interlayer distance (d) of 4.60 Å. Upon metalation, a shift is observed: Fe(Por)OP displays a peak at 2θ = 20.0° (d = 4.44 Å), indicating tighter packing, while Co(Por)OP shifts to 2θ = 17.7° (d = 5.01 Å), suggesting expanded interlayer distance. These shifts can also be attributed to differences in metals, where the nature of the metal center can induce structural changes and alter π–π stacking interactions. In the fluorinated samples (Fig. 1D), F(Por)OP displays two broad peaks at 2θ = 7.6° and 20.0°, corresponding to d = 11.6 Å and 4.44 Å, respectively. The low-angle peak can be attributed to the presence of fluorine substituents, which can increase interlayer spacing due to steric and electronic effects. FeF(Por)OP and CoF(Por)OP exhibit broad features at 2θ = 18.0° (d = 4.93 Å) and 16.0° (d = 5.54 Å), respectively, again reflecting the influence of the metal coordination and fluorine substituents on the structural organization and π–π interactions within the polymer network. SEM micrographs (Fig. 2 ) show that all the synthesized materials present morphologies of uniform spherical particles with dimensions at the micrometer scale. After metalation, the morphologies of the polymers retained the spherical shape. The average size of the unfluorinated series (Fig. 2A-C) is relatively larger than the fluorinated samples (Fig. 2D-F). This pattern can be attributed to the presence of fluorine substituents, which can hinder aggregation during polymerization, resulting in smaller particles. The metal content of the polymers was determined by ICP-OES. The molecular weight of the polymers was estimated based on their monomeric repeat structures in Figure S1. A calibration curve for both cobalt and iron was obtained using the ICP-OES data, as illustrated in Figure S2. To calculate the expected metal content in percentage, the atomic masses of cobalt and iron, along with the molecular weight of the monomeric repeat unit of the polymers, were used (Equation S1). The expected cobalt content shown in Table S1 was 10.2 % and 8.2 % for Co(Por)OP and CoF(Por)OP, respectively. For iron, the expected content was 9.8 % and 7.8 % in Fe(Por)OP and FeF(Por)OP, respectively. The actual metal content was calculated using Equation S2, based on the ICP-OES metal concentration in ppm (Table S2). This value was multiplied by the total digestion volume (0.05 L) and divided by the mass of the polymer used in sample preparation. The measured metal contents were 3.1 % and 1.3 % for CoF(Por)OP and Co(Por)OP, while FeF(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP showed 0.08 % and 1.2 % respectively. The polymers show 37.8 %, 12.6 %, 1.0%, and 12 % percent metalation for CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP, respectively. The lower than expected metal content can be attributed to the difficulty in metallating the porphyrin post polymerization, and incomplete digestion in aqua regia. Additionally, the significantly lower iron content observed in the iron samples can be attributed to the challenge of incorporating iron into porphyrins, as previous studies have reported [58] EDX analysis (Figure S1) confirms the elemental composition of the (Por)OP and M(Por)Ops materials. (Por)OP contains primarily carbon and nitrogen (Figure S1A), and F(Por)OP includes carbon, nitrogen, and fluorine (Figure S1B). Co(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP depicted in Figures S1C and S1E, show the presence of cobalt and iron. CoF(Por)OP and FeF(Por)OP exhibit cobalt, iron, and fluorine (Figure S1D and S1F). The XPS surveys of the samples shown in Figure S2 confirm Co, Fe, and F in CoF(Por)OP and FeF(Por)OP. Co(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP show their respective metals and a very weak F, which we attribute to contamination. As expected, F(Por)OP shows a strong F signal without metals, whereas (Por)OP shows neither metals nor significant F content. High-resolution spectra (Fig. 3 A–D) of each polymer show that for CoF(Por)OP, Co 2p3/2 appears at ∼780.5 eV and Co 2p1/2 at ∼796.5 eV with shake-up satellites at ∼785.6 eV and near ∼800.5–803 eV, a pattern characteristic of high-spin Co²⁺. Co(Por)OP shows Co 2p3/2 at ∼780.8 eV, Co 2p1/2 at ∼796.7 eV, and satellites at ∼785.8 and ∼803 eV, likewise consistent with Co²⁺. For FeF(Por)OP, a peak attributed to Fe 2p3/2 is observed at ∼711.6 eV with a satellite in the ∼718.5 eV region, which is consistent with Fe³⁺. In Fe(Por)OP, Fe 2p3/2 at ∼710.7 eV and Fe 2p1/2 at ∼724.3 eV, and satellites at ∼714, 718.5, and 730.8 eV suggest predominantly Fe³⁺ with a small downshift that can arise from the presence of some Fe2+ contribution. The measured energy difference (Co ≈16.0 eV; Fe ≈13.6 eV) is within typical ranges for Co²⁺ and Fe³⁺ porphyrin species. Additionally, EDX elemental mapping (Figures S3 and S4) shows a uniform elemental distribution across the scanned area, confirming the incorporation of Co and Fe into the porphyrin core of the organic polymer framework. 3.2 Oxygen evolution reaction The OER activity of the newly prepared porphyrin polymers was investigated by CV in O2-saturated and N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution on glassy carbon electrodes. Vulcan XC-72 was also loaded onto the glassy carbon electrode to increase the electrical conductivity. Fig. 4 A shows the polarization curves of all the synthesized polymers, as well as of pure carbon black, which was used in the deposition of catalysts on the working electrodes to enhance the conductivity. All the metalated species are electrocatalytically active with modest overpotentials (η) for oxygen production. At the current density (j) of 10 mA cm −2, η10 is 0.38 and 0.43 V vs. RHE for CoF(Por)OP and Co(Por)OP, respectively, while η10 is 0.46 V for both Fe(Por)OP and FeF(Por)OP. These electrochemical results are comparable to other reported porphyrin polymeric OER electrocatalysts [28,59]. Despite containing the same cobalt center, the two cobalt polymers exhibit distinct OER activities, where the fluorinated CoF(Por)OP has the highest performance. This enhancement can be attributed to the electron-withdrawing nature of fluorine, which can shift Co(III/II) redox potential and optimize the adsorption energetics of intermediates, leading to favorable binding energy and fast intermediate release [60]. This is not observed in the iron analogues, FeF(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP, which display similar performance. This can be explained by the lower metalation percentage in the iron samples, which leads to the absence of significant intrinsic site energetic changes, and suggests that their performance is instead limited by charge transport. Furthermore, both the metal-free polymers (Por)OP and F(Por)OP, show no appreciable catalytic current increase, implying that the metal centers are the catalytic active sites [61]. Similarly, carbon black exhibits no electrocatalytic activity. To further study the OER kinetics, Tafel analyses for CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, and Fe(Por)OP were obtained. Fig. 4B shows the Tafel plots fitted to the Tafel equation (η = b log j + a, where b is the Tafel slope and a is a constant) to obtain the Tafel slope. The Tafel slopes of CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, and Fe(Por)OP are determined to be 84.2, 72.8, 89.8, and 91.7 mV dec‑1 respectively, which are comparable to or better than previously reported similar porphyrin polymer-based catalytic systems (Table S4). These results further indicate that both metalloporphyrin polymeric materials are efficient and promising OER electrocatalysts. EIS measurements were conducted to gain insight into the charge transfer kinetics and electrical conductivity of as-synthesized porphyrin polymers. Figs. 5 A and 5B illustrate the obtained Nyquist plots of CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, and Fe(Por)OP, and the corresponding simulation fit by an equivalent circuit. The simulation curves are in good agreement with the experimental impedance data, thus validating the proposed equivalent circuit for all the synthesized materials. The arc diameter in the Nyquist plots is in the order of CoF(Por)OP< Co(Por)OP<Fe(Por)OP. The EIS spectrum of Co(Por)OP and CoF(Por)OP shows no semicircle at high frequencies, suggesting negligible charge transfer resistance at the interface between the electrode and electrolyte. At mid-frequency, a semicircle is observed, indicating a dominant charge transport process, while a diffusion limiting behavior is observed with the presence of a Warburg-type tail by the linear response at low frequencies. The EIS spectra of Fe(Por)OP demonstrate no diffusion limit, but the semicircle has a larger diameter compared to the cobalt analogs, pointing to a kinetically limited process. However, for FeF(Por)OP a linear feature indicative of mass transport limitations is observed in the Nyquist plot. In the fitted simulated equivalent circuit, Co-based (Por)Op (Fig. 5C) exhibits a less complex interfacial electron transfer pathway, described by a model comprising the resistance of the solution (Rs), and two resistive components: R1 and R2, attributed to the intrinsic resistance of the polymer and the interface between the polymer and glassy carbon substrate, respectively. The CPE element in the circuit corresponds to a constant phase element and accounts for the capacitive behavior arising from surface roughness, porosity, or heterogeneity at the interface. In contrast, in the equivalent circuit for Fe-based (Por)Op (Fig. 5D) an additional resistive element R3 is required to obtain a good fit, consistent with a more complex interfacial process. In this case, R1 still represents the polymer resistance, R2 is associated with the polymer and substrate interface, and R3 is attributed to an additional interfacial barrier, possibly related to less metal incorporation. The values in Table S5 correspond directly to these elements. Additionally, the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA), which is proportional to the double-layer capacitance (Cdl), was estimated by performing a cyclic voltammogram in the non-Faradaic region at various scan rates (Figure S5). After plotting the scan rate against the current density, a linear correlation was observed, corresponding to the Cdl values (Fig. 6 A). ECSA was calculated using equation: ECSA = C dl C s where the Cdl is the double layer capacitance obtained from the slope of the linear fit between the current and scan rate, and Cs is the specific capacitance of a flat surface per unit area under identical electrolyte conditions. For a 1.0 M KOH solution, Cs was taken as 0.04 mF cm-2, and for 0.5 M H2SO4 Cs was 0.035 mF cm-2 [62] The calculated ECSA values were 14.8 cm2 and 10.5 cm2 for CoF(Por)OP and Co(Por)OP and 9 cm2 and 9.75 cm2 for FeF(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP, respectively, highlighting the catalytic activity of Co-based PorOp (Fig. 6A). The activity of Co-based PorOp can be attributed to the higher catalytic active sites supported by ECSA values and LC-MS analysis, and to the enhanced electrical conductivity evidenced by the smaller semicircle diameter in the Nyquist plot and the simplified equivalent circuit model. To assess the intrinsic catalytic activity per active site, the LSV curves were normalized by the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) (Fig. 6B). Based on onset potential (η1), CoF(Por)OP initiates catalysis at the lowest value (0.47 V vs RHE), followed by Co(Por)OP (0.54 V), FeF(Por)OP (0.57 V), and Fe(Por)OP (0.59 V). However, when comparing intrinsic current densities (j) at a given potential, Co(Por)OP delivers the highest j-ECSA at 1.8 mA cm-2, followed by 1.6 mA cm-2 for CoF(Por)OP, while Fe(Por)OP shows 1.52 mA cm-2 , FeF(Por)OP 1.45 mA cm-2. Since the j are normalized by ECSA, these differences arise from electronic effects and the local coordination environment of the metal centers, rather than variations in surface area or catalyst loading. Furthermore, Co-based polymer catalytic activity is documented in the literature [63–65], and can be attributed to the strong interaction between the Co centers and hydroxide ions. The OER mechanism of metalloporphyrin based material involves transformation between the metal center and oxygen species [66]. This four electron process involves the key steps: adsorption of hydroxide ions, formation of oxo intermediate (*O), generation of peroxo (*OOH) species, and the release of molecular oxygen (O2) [56,67]. The formation of *O intermediate and its associated transition states are the rate-limiting steps [68]. Therefore, the synergy between the porphyrin metal center and the surrounding linker environment plays a critical role in facilitating charge transfer and lowering the activation energy [68]. Computational studies further reveal that the withdrawing nature of substituents on the porphyrin ring enhances the radical character of oxygen intermediates, leading to oxygen evolution [69] The durability of Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, CoF(Por)OP, and Fe(Por)OP was evaluated using chronoamperometry. Figure S6 shows the current density response as a function of time. While Co(Por)OP and CoF(Por)OP maintain nearly constant current density over 14 h of continuous electrolysis, FeF(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP show a noticeable decrease. The Faradaic efficiency (FE), determined from the evolved gas measured by gas chromatography (GC), was 99 % for the cobalt-based polymers and 70 % for the iron-based polymers. The GC calibration curve and the corresponding peak area integration are provided in Figure S7. 3.3 Hydrogen evolution reaction To investigate the HER activity of the metalloporphyrin polymers, CV in 0.5 M H2SO4 was performed, as shown in Fig. 7 A. All four polymers display comparable polarization behavior, with η10 of 0.61, 0.63, 0.6, and 0.62 V vs RHE for CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, FeF(Por)OP, and Fe(Por)OP, respectively. The corresponding Tafel slopes of 133, 131, 167, and 148 mV dec‑1, respectively (Fig. 7B), suggest a sluggish Volmer step is dominant for all polymers while not accounting for differences in metal type and presence or absence of fluorine. The Volmer step corresponds to the initial reaction where a proton in solution is reduced and adsorbed onto the catalyst surface as hydrogen atom (H + + e - → H*). The EIS data in Figures S8A and S8B illustrate that the arc diameter in the Nyquist plots follows the trend: FeF(Por)OP <CoF(Por)OP=Co(Por)OP<Fe(Por)OP. The simulated equivalent circuit (Figure S8C) is comprised of the solution resistance RS, the intrinsic resistance of the polymer (R1), the interface between the catalyst and substrate (R2), and an additional resistance component (R3) that can be associated with further interfacial or charge transfer processes. Table S6 includes the values corresponding to these elements. The cyclic voltammetry data obtained in the non-Faradaic region (Figure S9) were used to obtain Cdl illustrated in Fig. 8 A, revealing that the CoF(Por)OP and FeF(Por)OP have ECSA values of 17 and 14 cm2 , while Co(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP exhibit 13.9 and 12.5 cm2, respectively. Furthermore, the j-ECSA LSV was obtained, revealing that FeF(Por)OP has the highest j-ECSA of 2.2 mA cm-2 while Co(Por)OP has 1.86 mA cm-2 and Fe(Por)OP and CoF(Por)OP with 1.7 and 1.78 mA cm-2, respectively. These results indicate that all polymers display comparable intrinsic catalytic performance. Although the HER performance of these polymers is very similar, this highlights their bifunctional activity. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized two metalloporphyrin-based polymers with cobalt and iron and their fluorinated version, which was obtained from a facile one-step condensation reaction of pyrrole and the respective aldehyde in the presence of propionic acid. Both polymers were implemented as substrates for direct metalation using cobalt and iron to prepare four different metalloporphyrin organic polymers. These materials were used for oxygen and hydrogen evolution from alkaline and acidic aqueous media through electrochemical means. All the metalated porphyrin polymers exhibit efficient and durable OER and HER electrocatalysts by requiring η10 of 0.38, 0.43, 0.46 V vs. RHE for the OER in CoF(Por)OP, Co(Por)OP, and for both FeF(Por)OP and Fe(Por)OP, respectively. The metal-free polymers are catalytically inert under the same conditions. While the current study focuses on the electrocatalytic performance of metalloporphyrin polymers for water splitting, these materials also exhibit potential in other energy conversion and storage applications. Metalloporphyrin based systems have been explored for electrochemical CO2 reduction by stabilizing intermediates such as *COOH or *CO [70,71] Their inherent electrical conductivity, and their ability to coordinate metal ions enable them to achieve reversible redox processes making them suitable candidates for use as electrode materials for metal-ion and lithium batteries [72] Furthermore, porphyrins have intense absorption in the visible region, making them suitable for light-driven catalysis [73] Funding sources This work was supported as part of the Cleantech FWP 100898 funded by the U.S. Department of Energy, Office of Science, Basic Energy Sciences. coredata.dc:description: Metalloporphyrin polymers have attracted much attention due to their efficient electron transfer, their ability to form metal-oxo adducts, and due to their improved mass transport and efficiency. Here, we report cobalt and iron porphyrin-based organic polymers as heterogeneous electrocatalysts for the oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction (OER and HER) in basic and acidic solutions. The porphyrin organic polymers (Por)OP and F(Por)P were synthesized from a one-step condensation reaction without further cross-coupling followed by direct metalation to form the metalloporphyrin polymers: Co(Por)OP, CoF(Por)P, Fe(Por)OP, and FeF(Por)P. Both metalated porphyrin polymers are active for the oxygen and hydrogen evolution reaction with moderate overpotentials and Tafel slope in the range of 72.8 to 91.7 mV dec‑1 for OER and 131 to 167 mV dec‑1 for HER. At the same time, the metal-free (Por)OP and F(Por)OP show poor catalytic activity. These metalloporphyrin organic polymers show a remarkable stability of up to 14 h, whereas the cobalt polymers exhibit a Faradaic efficiency of 99 % for OER.
